image.altText: Crime figure Gavin Preston looks unsmilingly into the camera as he poses for a photo.

items.synopsis: A Melbourne underworld figure has been killed and another man has been critically injured in what police have described as an organised crime shooting outside a cafe in the city's north-west.

title.children: Gunmen still at large after Melbourne underworld figure shot dead outside cafe

image.altText: The top of an old building collapsed with a lot of rubble on the ground and a destroyed car in the distance

items.synopsis: The epicentre in the High Atlas Mountains, known as Ighil, is in a region of small farming villages about 70km from the city of Marrakesh.

title.children: 'If one falls, it will cause others to collapse': Hundreds stranded in Morocco as earthquake death toll rises to over 1000

image.altText: A grey Mazda vehicle crashed into a pole.

items.synopsis: Victoria Police say a 26-year-old Melton West man faces multiple charges over a fatal incident on Bourke St.

title.children: Man charged with murder over deadly Melbourne CBD incident

image.altText: A homeless person sleeps on a blanket in a Brisbane park

items.synopsis: WA council officers duty-bound to act on increased reports of people living in sheds are being urged by their shire president to show leniency in the face of a housing crisis.

title.children: 'Don't throw people out on the street': Call for restraint in unapproved housing crackdown

image.altText: Two young surfers walk in from the surf at sunset on Legian beach near Kuta on Bali.

items.synopsis: Indonesia is expected to be one of the world's fastest growing economies in the decades ahead and WA is in prime position to take advantage of its rise, writes state political reporter Keane Bourke.

title.children: If the WA premier can convince people Indonesia offers more than just Bali, big rewards are on offer

image.altText: A Wallabies player holds the ball with his left hand as he runs away to score a try at the Rugby World Cup.

items.synopsis: After five consecutive Test losses under coach Eddie Jones this year, the Wallabies break through for a vital 35-15 win over Georgia at Stade de France in Paris. Follow our live blog.

title.children: Wallabies defeat Georgia to open Rugby World Cup campaign on positive note

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's the first time the Wallabies have won a match in 2023. Amazing stuff. In truth, that was pretty comfortable for the Aussies. A strong performance from the outset and that killed off Georgia pretty quickly. They had their moments late in the contest but otherwise it was mostly Australia who were in firm control.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Full tmie: Wallabies 35-15 Georgia

children.content: It's the first time the Wallabies have won a match in 2023. Amazing stuff.
In truth, that was pretty comfortable for the Aussies.
A strong performance from the outset and that killed off Georgia pretty quickly.
They had their moments late in the contest but otherwise it was mostly Australia who were in firm control.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Beka Gigashvili! Georgia have a good platform off the back of a lineout. They first try to crash their skipper Merab Sharikadze over, but when he is held short, the massive sub prop Gigashvili crashed over. It's 35-15 now.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 80' Georgia score a consolation!

children.content: Georgia have a good platform off the back of a lineout.
They first try to crash their skipper Merab Sharikadze over, but when he is held short, the massive sub prop Gigashvili crashed over.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Ben Donaldson gets another! It was off the back of some really good pressure that the Georgia simply could not handle. There was a penalty coming, so Carter Gordon looked up, spun a pass nicely into the centre field to Donaldson, who ran a perfect line to score under the posts. He converts his own score. The score is 35-8.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 69' Wallabies score another to seal the bonus point!

children.content: It was off the back of some really good pressure that the Georgia simply could not handle.
There was a penalty coming, so Carter Gordon looked up, spun a pass nicely into the centre field to Donaldson, who ran a perfect line to score under the posts.

image.altText: Brisbane Lions forward Charlie Cameron sprints away from goal, with his finger pointed in celebration as the crowd cheers.

items.synopsis: Brisbane Lions produce a brilliant attacking display to move through to another home prelim, downing Port Adelaide at the Gabba with the help of 200-gamer Charlie Cameron.

title.children: Lions rampant as home side tears Power apart on way to a home prelim

image.altText: A Giants AFL player jumps in the air in celebration as a smiling teammate points at him after a goal.

items.synopsis: The Giants are into a cut-throat semifinal after an impressive elimination final performance that ends St Kilda's season.

title.children: Giants make a big, big sound at the MCG to end St Kilda's season

image.altText: Narendra Modi sits at a table at the G20.

items.synopsis: World leaders have called for the upholding of international law including territorial sovereignty, while failing to condemn the war in Ukraine, after concerns there would not be an agreement for the first time in the summit's history.

title.children: G20 leaders make joint declaration but concede on Ukraine war condemnation

image.altText: A man in suit looking up at the camera

items.synopsis: Current and past employees spoke up about the bullying and mistreatment they faced while working for the famous US TV host.

title.children: 'It's embarrassing': Jimmy Fallon apologises to The Tonight Show staff for toxic work culture

image.altText: A group of girls walking up a street with a megaphone.

items.synopsis: A spokesperson says the company is investigating workers' concerns. However, staff say there is still confusion about how much they should be paid.

title.children: Mint My Desk staff walk off job for second time over alleged underpayment

image.altText: a large aboriginal flag flying above a large group of people at a city march

items.synopsis: The latest poll result for the Voice referendum shows more bad news for Yes with rapidly declining support across all demographics. For Yes to win from here it needs to turn things around fast and undecided voters are in the spotlight, writes Casey Briggs.

title.children: Uninformed, bored and apathetic: Voters are turning against the Voice in the polls

image.altText: Mangosuthu Buthelezi speaks with one arm raised in the air wearing an orange shirt.

items.synopsis: Controversial South African politician and traditional minister of the Zulu ethnic group Prince Mangosuthu Buthelezi has died at the age of 95.

title.children: Controversial South African political figure and Zulu minister Mangosuthu Buthelezi dies at 95

image.altText: Fire rages behind the canopy of both a eucalyptus and pine tree.

items.synopsis: From southern Europe to the east coast of the United States, debate is raging over how vulnerable the eucalyptus tree is to fire and whether it's doing more harm than good.

title.children: Australia's iconic eucalyptus was shipped across the globe. Now, this flammable tree has 'gone feral'

image.altText: Young pilot in plane cockpit

items.synopsis: Hayden McDonald is on a solo mission to prove he should be judged on his ability, not his disability.

title.children: Pilot 'sick and tired' of being treated like a 'burden' takes off to challenge assumptions

image.altText: Three male rugby league players embrace after winning a game of football, wearing red, white and blue shirts

items.synopsis: Despite losing several key men to injury and ill-discipline, the Roosters score an incredible finals win over Cronulla in the Shire.

title.children: 'It got really wild': Sin-bins, injuries and last-gasp heroics as Roosters end Cronulla's NRL season

image.altText: A woman with dark brown hair sleeping in a bed, made in white linen, next to a gold alarm clock on a bedside table

items.synopsis: Dreams keep our brains ticking over. They wash the thoughts from the day's events at a molecular level. They might even help us imagine what's possible during our waking hours, write Drew Dawson and Madeline Sprajcer.

title.children: The science of dreams and nightmares: What is going on in our brains while we're sleeping?

image.altText: Catherine King stands at lecturn in front of airport signage

items.synopsis: The government's Qatar decision isn't just about preventing Australians from accessing more flights at cheaper prices, but about the binfire that is our national carrier and its multiple failures to treat its staff and customers with respect, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: The underlying problem behind the Qantas binfire

image.altText: Cycling city Copenhagen sprints to become first carbon-neutral capital

items.synopsis: How did Danish pharmaceutical company Novo Nordisk become the proprietor of one of the most in-demand products in the world?

title.children: A Danish pharmaceuticals-maker has just become the biggest company in Europe — all because of one drug

image.altText: a cow with lumps and lesions on its skin.

items.synopsis: Indonesian restrictions on northern Australian cattle have been lifted, providing relief to pastoralists who want to see export ships organised quickly to clear a livestock backlog.

title.children: Northern Australia cattle producers welcome lift on Indonesian export ban and restrictions

image.altText: Photo of older man with glasses DJing.

items.synopsis: Simon Zaicz went from tour-managing rock bands like Split Enz and Australian Crawl to become Pa to a legion of bush doofers.

title.children: 'Godfather' of doof trance DJ pushing 70 and still a weapon on the festival stage

image.altText: A man stands smiling next to a sculpture on a swing with bushland behind him.

items.synopsis: Kerry Sibly chose the "serious" career path and became an engineer, but struggled with depression. Now he's an artist and can't stop smiling.

title.children: How art helped turn the 'colour of the world' back on again for Kerry

image.altText: A small spotted fish with legs lies on sand.

items.synopsis: Finding a spotted handfish in the wild can be like looking for a needle in a haystack, so when one washed up on a beach in Tasmania, and although dead, it still had scientists excited.

title.children: It may be dead, but the chance discovery of this handfish still has scientists excited

image.altText: Sunshine Coast mega-mansion demolition

items.synopsis: The building, which had sweeping ocean views, was the centre of controversy for decades, with neighbours even launching a court bid to have the newly built palatial residence knocked down.

title.children: This 'extreme dream' McMansion with a nuclear bunker is being demolished. And neighbours are relieved

image.altText: An illustration of a person's hand placing a ballot paper into a ballot box held by someone else's outstretched hands.

items.synopsis: Conservative think tank Institute of Public Affairs has been accused of trying to "interfere with Australia's democratic processes via the education system" after publishing an "egregious" classroom resource about the Voice to Parliament referendum.

title.children: Voice classroom materials labelled 'shallow attempt to inflict conservative views' on school children

image.altText: Unidentified woman in foreground holding black and white holding ultrasound of baby scan with blue line around the scan

items.synopsis: An Australian woman caught up in a surrogacy scandal in Greece has spoken about her emotional ordeal as she desperately fights to be allowed to keep her baby.

title.children: Sarah has a baby due in October. She fears she may never get to meet it

image.altText: A hand pulls a tap in a box to pour out red wine into a glass.

items.synopsis: Winemakers want consumers to stop the snobbery towards cask wine and embrace it as a climate-friendly and cost-effective alternative to glass bottles.

title.children: Some winemakers are putting their best wines in casks. They say it is better than glass

image.altText: Close up of spider with eggs

items.synopsis: You probably have a daddy-long-legs in your house right now – but there's so much about them that is commonly misunderstood. We bust five common myths.

title.children: Are daddy-long-legs venomous spiders with inadequate fangs? We bust five myths about this iconic housemate

image.altText: Two Australian rowers competing at the world titles in Belgrade

items.synopsis: Nikki Ayers and Jeld Altschwager clinch Australia's first gold medal at the World Rowing Championship in Belgrade, while also qualifying the boat for the Paralympic Games in Paris.

title.children: Aussie duo claim gold at world rowing titles

image.altText: A middle-aged white woman lying in bed looking exhausted

items.synopsis: People with myalgic encephalomyelitis, also known as chronic fatigue syndrome, say society has long underestimated and downplayed their struggles. They share what their lives are really like.

title.children: Dee feels like a prisoner in her own body and wants more people to know the truth about her illness

image.altText: Two women, one in a white gown holding flowers, the other in a pink dress smile and look at the camera.

items.synopsis: Nell Kelly wasn't just a dressmaker, she was a couturier. She left behind a fashion legacy of flowing gowns, detailed beadwork, and intricate embroidery which is still being celebrated today.

title.children: Celebrating the dressmaker who designed gowns to fit women 'perfectly'

image.altText: a Glistening-green Tanager sits in the crest of a leaf

items.synopsis: Photos of two ducks in Peth and darter on a foggy winter morning in Victoria are among the winning entries this year.

title.children: Bird Photographer of the Year winners revealed
